abstracts.cdata!:
Prior to Independence, the Narmada River
            Basin area was mainly divided between a number of Princely
            states which lacked the, planning, technical, and fiscal
            capabilities to undertake the major works involved in
            regulating the river . In the 1950's and 1960's,
            ambitious, Flaps were drawn up for development of the
            Narmada River but most of the plans were held up because of
            inter-state disputes over the allocation of water. Thus,
            today, the water resource remains virtually undeveloped.
            This annex describes the planning process of the total
            Narmada river development -- Gujarat or the Sardar Sarovar
            Project (SSP) and the development as presently envisaged.
            The complexity of the project and the many direct and
            indirect ways in which it will affect the welfare of the
            people of the beneficiary states, required a
            multi-disciplinary planning approach. Further complicating
            the planning process is the time frame of 22 years over
            which the project would be implemented and during which many
            unforeseen events may take place. Thus, the planners faced
            the challenge of planning with uncertainty. As the SSP is
            only one of several large reservoir projects planned for
            regulation of the Narmada River, the planning had to take
            account of the timing, scope, and objectives of upstream developments.
